eu.toolchain.concurrent

Class ConcurrentCompletable<T>

  • java.lang.Object
    • eu.toolchain.concurrent.AbstractImmediate<T>
      • eu.toolchain.concurrent.ConcurrentCompletable<T>
  • Type Parameters:
    T - type of the completable
    All Implemented Interfaces:
    Completable<T>, Handle<T>, Stage<T>

    public class ConcurrentCompletable<T>
extends AbstractImmediate<T>
implements Handle<T>, Completable<T>
    A thread-safe implementation of Completable.

    The callback uses the calling thread to execute result listeners, see complete(Object), and handle(Handle) for details.

    Author:
    udoprog

    • Constructor Summary

    • Constructor Detail

      • ConcurrentCompletable

        public ConcurrentCompletable(Caller caller)
        Setup a concurrent completable that uses a custom caller implementation.

        The provided caller implementation will be called from the calling thread of handle(Handle), or other public methods interacting with this completable.

        It is therefore suggested to provide an implementation that supports delegating tasks to a separate thread pool.

        Parameters:
        caller - The caller implementation to use.

      • thenApply

        public <U> Stage<U> thenApply(Function<? super T,? extends U> fn)
        Description copied from interface: Stage
        Transform the value of the current stage into another type using an immediate function.

        Translates the result of a completed stage as it becomes available: 

        
   operation().thenApply(result -> result / 2);
        Specified by:
        thenApply in interface Stage<T>
        Type Parameters:
        U - the type of the newly applied stage
        Parameters:
        fn - transformation to use
        Returns:
        the applied stage

      • thenCompose

        public <U> Stage<U> thenCompose(Function<? super T,? extends Stage<U>> fn)
        Description copied from interface: Stage
        Compose the current stage with the given function.

        When the current stage has completed, calls the given function with the result of the current stage. 

        
   Stage<A> a = op1();
   Stage<B> a.thenCompose(result -> op2(result));
        Specified by:
        thenCompose in interface Stage<T>
        Type Parameters:
        U - type of the composed stage
        Parameters:
        fn - the function to use when transforming the value
        Returns:
        the composed stage

        Apply a failed stage.

        This acts like a try-catch, where the provided function is the catch operation.

      • thenComposeCaught

        public Stage<T> thenComposeCaught(Function<? super Throwable,? extends Stage<T>> fn)
        Description copied from interface: Stage
        Compose a failed stage.

        This acts like a try-catch, where the composed stage is the catch operation.

        If the intent is to re-throw after running the catch operation, use Stage.withOther(java.util.function.Supplier)

        Specified by:
        thenComposeCaught in interface Stage<T>
        Parameters:
        fn - the transformation to use
        Returns:
        the composed stage

      • withCloser

        public Stage<T> withCloser(Supplier<? extends Stage<Void>> complete,
                           Supplier<? extends Stage<Void>> other)
        Description copied from interface: Stage
        Run one of the provided stages when this stage ends up in a given state.

        This is typically used to implement catch-then-rethrow style operations, like the following example: 

        
   beginTransaction().thenCompose(tx -> {
     return oper2(tx).withCloser(tx::commit, tx::rollback);
   });
        Specified by:
        withCloser in interface Stage<T>
        Parameters:
        complete - stage to run when this stage ends in a complete state
        other - stage to run when this stage ends in a non-complete state, if the state is failed, any exception thrown in this block will suppress the original exception
        Returns:
        a new stage that depends on the supplied stage
